metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: How To Add CSS
When a browser reads a style sheet, it will format the HTML document according to the information in the style sheet.
content.html: When a browser reads a style sheet, it will format the HTML document according to the information in the style sheet.

content.text: Three Ways to Insert CSS
There are three ways of inserting a style sheet:
content.html: There are three ways of inserting a style sheet:

content.text: External CSS
With an external style sheet, you can change the look of an entire website by changing just one file!
content.html: With an external style sheet, you can change the look of an entire website by changing just one file!

content.text: Each HTML page must include a reference to the external style sheet file inside the <link> element, inside the head section.
content.html: Each HTML page must include a reference to the external style sheet file inside the <link> element, inside the head section.

content.code:
This is a heading

This is a paragraph.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="mystyle.css">
</head>
<body>

<h1>This is a heading</h1>
<p>This is a paragraph.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: An external style sheet can be written in any text editor, and must be saved with a .css extension.
content.html: An external style sheet can be written in any text editor, and must be saved with a .css extension.

content.text: The external .css file should not contain any HTML tags.
content.html: The external .css file should not contain any HTML tags.

content.text: Here is how the "mystyle.css" file looks:
content.html: Here is how the "mystyle.css" file looks:

syntaxHighlighting.text: body {  background-color: lightblue;}h1 {  color: navy;  margin-left: 20px;}

content.code: body {  background-color: lightblue;}h1 {  color: navy;  margin-left: 20px;}

syntax_highlighting.text: body {  background-color: lightblue;}h1 {  color: navy;  margin-left: 20px;}

content.code_html:
body {
  background-color: lightblue;
}

h1 {
  color: navy;
  margin-left: 20px;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: body {  background-color: lightblue;}h1 {  color: navy;  margin-left: 20px;}

content.text: Note: Do not add a space between the property value (20) and the unit (px): Incorrect (space): margin-left: 20 px; Correct (no space): margin-left: 20px;
content.html:
Note: Do not add a space between the property value (20) and the unit (px):
Incorrect (space): margin-left: 20 px;
Correct (no space): margin-left: 20px;

content.text: Internal CSS
An internal style sheet may be used if one single HTML page has a unique style.
content.html: An internal style sheet may be used if one single HTML page has a unique style.

content.text: The internal style is defined inside the <style> element, inside the head section.
content.html: The internal style is defined inside the <style> element, inside the head section.

content.code:
This is a heading

This is a paragraph.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
body {
  background-color: linen;
}

h1 {
  color: maroon;
  margin-left: 40px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h1>This is a heading</h1>
<p>This is a paragraph.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Inline CSS
An inline style may be used to apply a unique style for a single element.
content.html: An inline style may be used to apply a unique style for a single element.

content.text: To use inline styles, add the style attribute to the relevant element. The style attribute can contain any CSS property.
content.html: To use inline styles, add the style attribute to the relevant element. The style attribute can contain any CSS property.

content.code:
This is a heading

This is a paragraph.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<h1 style="color:blue;text-align:center;">This is a heading</h1>
<p style="color:red;">This is a paragraph.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Tip: An inline style loses many of the advantages of a style sheet (by mixing content with presentation). Use this method sparingly.
content.html: Tip: An inline style loses many of the advantages of a style sheet (by mixing content with presentation). Use this method sparingly.

content.text: Multiple Style Sheets
If some properties have been defined for the same selector (element) in different style sheets, the value from the last read style sheet will be used.
content.html: If some properties have been defined for the same selector (element) in different style sheets, the value from the last read style sheet will be used.

content.code_html:
h1 {
  color: navy;
}

h1 {
  color: orange;   
}

<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="mystyle.css">
<style>
h1 {
  color: orange;
}
</style>
</head>

<head>
<style>
h1 {
  color: orange;
}
</style>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="mystyle.css">
</head>

content.text: Cascading Order
What style will be used when there is more than one style specified for an HTML element?
content.html: What style will be used when there is more than one style specified for an HTML element?

content.text: All the styles in a page will "cascade" into a new "virtual" style sheet by the following rules, where number one has the highest priority:
content.html: All the styles in a page will "cascade" into a new "virtual" style sheet by the following rules, where number one has the highest priority:

content.text: So, an inline style has the highest priority, and will override external and internal styles and browser defaults.
content.html: So, an inline style has the highest priority, and will override external and internal styles and browser defaults.
